body:
The default popup for `vim.lsp.buf.hover()` shows additional "Error" syntax highlighting, as per the following image:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16781840/104397005-cb511780-5586-11eb-8ece-61354bac614c.png)

It appears that the issue is  due to a conflict in `util.fancy_floating_markdown()` where markdown syntax highlighting doesn't recognise the additional padding added on the sides (ref `runtime/lua/vim/lsp/handlers.lua:249`). I can confirm that this is a non-issue if pad_left and pad_right is set to 0 instead.

- `nvim --version`: NVIM v0.5.0-dev+1015-g0860d9c16
- language server name/version: gopls devel
- Operating system/version: macos

<details>
<summary>lsp.log</summary>
[ DEBUG ] 2021-01-13T10:00:01+0800 ] /usr/local/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/handlers.lua:394 ]	"default_handler"	"textDocument/hover"	{  bufnr = 3,  client_id = 2,  params = {    contents = {      kind = "markdown",      value = '```go\ntype Profile struct {\n\tCPU    string `flag:"profile.cpu" help:"write CPU profile to this file"`\n\tMemory string `flag:"profile.mem" help:"write memory profile to this file"`\n\tTrace  string `flag:"profile.trace" help:"write trace log to this file"`\n}\n```\n\n[`tool.Profile` on pkg.go.dev](https://pkg.go.dev/golang.org/x/tools/internal/tool?utm_source=gopls#Profile)\n\nProfile can be embedded in your application struct to automatically\nadd command line arguments and handling for the common profiling methods\\.\n'    },    range = {      end = {        character = 12,        line = 40      },      start = {        character = 5,        line = 40      }    }  }}
</details>

### Steps to reproduce using `nvim -u NORC`

Using the following minimal config

```
call plug#begin()
Plug 'neovim/nvim-lspconfig'
call plug#end()
lua require 'lspconfig'.gopls.setup{}
```

Navigate to any go file and run `:lua vim.lsp.buf.hover()`

### Actual behaviour

As mentioned above

### Expected behaviour

There should be no additional "error" syntax highlights

Ok, it seems like the only thing all of these groups have in common is that they are all syntax links to the Error group, but currently in vim, there's no way to clear links given only the target (Error) name. My recommendation (for the forseeable future) would be to choose a colorscheme that doesn't highlight errors like onedark.

* If we `:hi clear Error` it clears it for both the floating window and the buffer
* If we `:syntax clear Error`, it doesn't clear anything, since the link to Error is already set
* If we `:syntax clear goSpaceError`, it only clears for go, so we'd need to list every offending syntax rule, and we can't maintain a list of these syntax groups since it's unweildy, and plugins are free to add their own
